newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia's Optus doubles main route capacity.
newsitem.headline: Australia's Optus doubles main route capacity.

text.p: Optus Communications said on Monday that it had doubled the capacity of its optical fibre network between Australia's two largest cities, Sydney and Melbourne.
Optus, which is 49 percent-owned by Cable & Wireless Plc, said it had put into service a 10 gigabit transmission system that was about 2,500 kilometres long.
The system could support more than 120,000 simultaneous phone calls on a single pair of fibres, which was four times greater than other systems used in Australia, Optus said.

"The increased capacity on our busiest network route will cater for the anticipated increase in demand in the newly deregulated environment," Optus Technical Director Cliff McElveen said in a statement.
Australia's telecommunications industry was fully deregulated on July 1.
Optus' other major shareholder is Mayne Nickless Ltd with 24.9 percent. The rest is owned by local institutions.
